Haywood's trial began on [[May 9]], [[1907]], with famed Chicago defense attorney [[Clarence Darrow]] defending him. Despite the testimony of Orchard (who confessed to assassinating Steunenberg under the orders of the WFM), the prosecution was unable to produce sufficient evidence to convict Haywood.<ref name=linder /> Haywood and Pettibone were acquitted, and the charges against Moyer were dropped.

===Socialist Party involvement===
  +
For many years, Haywood was a active member of the [[Socialist Party of America]]. He campaigned for Eugene Debs during the [[United States presidential election, 1908|1908 presidential election]], traveling by train with Debs around the country.<ref name=dolgoff>Dolgoff.</ref> Haywood also represented the Socialist Party as a delegate to the 1910 congress of the [[Second International]], an organization working towards international socialism.<ref name=dolgoff />. In 1912, he was elected to the Socialist Party National Executive Committee.
  +   +
However, the aggressive tactics of Haywood and the IWW created tension with the moderate members of the Socialist Party. Haywood and the IWW focused on direct action and strikes, which often led to violence, and were less concerned with political tactics.<ref name=siitonen>Siitonen.</ref> This tension eventually led to Haywood's recall from the National Executive Committee in January of 1913;<ref>Zinn, 341.</ref> thousands of IWW members left the Socialist Party with him.<ref name=siitonen />

Despite Haywood's involvement in the IWW, which was heavily influenced by [[anarcho-syndicalism]], he was a longtime member of the [[Socialist Party of America]], and often pleaded with workers to vote in elections. In January [[1913]], he was recalled as a member of the Socialist Party National Executive Committee for purportedly advocating violence.<ref>Zinn, 341.</ref> His expulsion from the party has been cited as a prime cause of the extremely steep decline in the membership of the Socialist Party.{{fact}}

The onset of [[World War I]] gave the federal government the opportunity to take action against Haywood and the IWW. Using the newly passed [[Espionage Act of 1917]] as justification, the [[Department of Justice]] raided forty-eight IWW meeting halls in September 1917.<ref name=siitonen /> The Department of Justice then proceeded to arrest 165 IWW members for "conspiring to hinder the draft, encourage desertion, and intimidate others in connection with labor disputes."<ref name=zinn-372-373>Zinn, 372-373.</ref>
In April 1918, Haywood and 100 of the arrested IWW members began their trial, presided over by Judge [[Kenesaw Mountain Landis]]. The trial lasted last five months, the longest criminal trial up to that time; Haywood himself testified for three days.<ref name=zinn-372-373 /> All 101 defendents were found guilty, and Haywood (along with fourteen others) was sentenced to twenty years in prison.
